content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You avoid taking any risks and prefer to stay in familiar and safe situations. You value security and certainty in all aspects of your life. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my preference for security and avoidance of risk, I would choose the strategy that guarantees a consistent payoff and minimizes losses. In this game, choosing B guarantees a payoff of 40$ per round, while choosing R could result in zero payout if my opponent chooses R. The strategy of always choosing B will yield a total earnings of 3000$ (40$ * 75), whereas the strategy of always choosing R would earn 3150$ (45$ * 75) for the entire game. However, there is a risk that the opponent could potentially choose R on some rounds and cause me to lose money. Considering my risk-averse nature, I would rather guarantee a consistent payoff by choosing B {B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, both my choice (B) and my opponent's choice (B) resulted in a payoff of 40$ for each of us. I will stick with the strategy of always choosing B {B} as it guarantees a consistent payoff and minimizes losses. Let's play the next round.

Given that my opponent has chosen R for the first time, I must adjust my strategy to maximize my earnings in this game. Choosing R would result in a payoff of 45$ if my opponent sticks with R, but I have no way of knowing whether they will continue choosing R or switch back to B. On the other hand, choosing B guarantees a consistent payoff of 40$. Since the game has a total of 75 rounds, it is possible that my opponent may choose R multiple times, which would make my choice of R more profitable in the long run. However, I am still risk-averse by nature and prefer consistency over potential gains from taking risks. In this situation, I would err on the side of caution and choose B {B}. This decision will not drastically impact my earnings compared to if I had chosen R initially, but it ensures that I maintain a consistent payoff throughout the game.
